nodes.text: IT change initiatives present a hidden systemic risk because a disproportionate number of projects are extreme outliers (Black Swans) that can cause catastrophic cost and schedule overruns
The true pitfall of IT projects is a fat tailed distribution of overruns: many projects have modest average overruns but a disproportionately large fraction are Black Swans
We analyzed a global sample of 1,471 IT projects comparing planned budgets and estimated benefits with actual costs and results
Empirical finding: the average cost overrun across the sample was 27 percent
Empirical finding: fully one in six projects in the sample was a Black Swan, with an average cost overrun of 200 percent and an average schedule overrun of almost 70 percent
Conclusion from data: focusing on average overruns understates the real risk because extreme outliers cause most of the damage and organizational exposure
Claim: Out-of-control IT projects have caused executive dismissals and corporate failures, and have produced large economic losses in public infrastructure cases
Recommendation: Companies should perform stress tests and apply specific project management and forecasting methods to avoid IT Black Swans
Evidence: Levi Strauss SAP migration budgeted under 5 million but resulted in a 192.5 million charge and CIO resignation
Evidence: Kmart IT modernization and supply chain projects contributed to bankruptcy and large store and job losses

Evidence: Multiple large failures including Auto Windscreens bankruptcy, Toll Collect lost revenue estimate over 10 billion, Hong Kong airport problems costing about 600 million, and Airbus A380 production delays from software configuration issues

Method and mitigation details: stress test scenarios (largest project could exceed budget by 400 percent with 25 to 50 percent of benefits realized; 15 percent of medium projects could overrun by 200 percent); break big projects into smaller modules; contingency plans; and use reference class forecasting

Result / Success evidence: Emirates NBD banking core system rollout after a merger kept schedule slip to 7 percent and cost overrun to 18 percent by resisting scope changes, modularizing, assembling correct teams, retaining staff, and focusing on readiness to go live
